BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow above the tree line: Dry avalanches at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate southerly wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. Dry and moist avalanches can be released in near-surface layers and reach quite a large size, caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
In particular low altitudes: As the moisture increases moist and wet snow slides are possible, even medium-sized ones. In particular on very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2400 m. The rain gave rise on Tuesday to thorough wetting of the snowpack below the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. Occasionally large natural avalanches are not ruled out. This applies in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 1900 m, as well as at the base of rock walls. The avalanche-prone wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects at high altitude. These places are barely recognisable in the fog. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of the precipitation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 1600 m. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the new snow represent the main danger. The large quantity of fresh snow and local mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Mostly the avalanches in these loacations are medium-sized. More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies in particular.

With the end of the intense snowfall, the activity of gliding avalanches will increase. This applies in particular on steep, snow-free grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall. 20 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1600 m. The wind will be light to moderate. The wind will be strong in the south. Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow will be deposited on the wet surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated on Thursday. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and local mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. In isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies in particular.

With the end of the snowfall, the activity of gliding avalanches will increase. This applies in particular on steep, snow-free grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. Above approximately 1700 m snow will fall in the northeast. The wind will be strong. New snow is lying mostly on a wet old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack will consolidate on Thursday. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the new snow represent the main danger. The large quantity of fresh snow and local mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Mostly the avalanches in these loacations are medium-sized. More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies in particular.

With the end of the intense snowfall, the activity of gliding avalanches will increase. This applies in particular on steep, snow-free grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall. 20 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1600 m. The wind will be light to moderate. The wind will be strong in the south. Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow will be deposited on the wet surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated on Thursday. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow above the tree line: Dry avalanches at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. Dry and moist avalanches can be released in near-surface layers and reach medium size, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
In particular low altitudes: As the moisture increases more moist and wet snow slides are possible, but they will be mostly small. In particular on very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2400 m. The rain gave rise on Tuesday to thorough wetting of the snowpack below the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions there is still a very large amount of snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes. As a consequence of new snow and wind avalanches are possible towards the evening, even large ones in isolated cases. Slight decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the snowfall level drops. The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening. The rain gave rise on Tuesday to thorough wetting of the snowpack below the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions there is still a very large amount of snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes. As a consequence of new snow and wind avalanches are possible towards the evening, even large ones in isolated cases. Slight decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the snowfall level drops. The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening. The rain gave rise on Tuesday to thorough wetting of the snowpack below the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions there is still a very large amount of snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the new snow represent the main danger. The fresh snow and local mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. In isolated cases the avalanches in these loacations are medium-sized. More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies in particular.

With the end of the snowfall, the activity of gliding avalanches will increase. This applies in particular on steep, snow-free grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall. 10 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1200 m. The wind will be light to moderate. The fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow will be deposited on the wet surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated on Thursday. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the new snow represent the main danger. The fresh snow and local small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In isolated cases avalanches can release the saturated snowpack. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Sometimes the avalanches in these loacations are medium-sized. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the danger is a little higher.

More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of prolonged bright spells this applies in particular. Mostly the avalanches are only small.

With the end of the snowfall, the activity of gliding avalanches will increase. This applies in particular on steep, snow-free grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall. 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1400 m. The wind will be light to moderate. Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow will be deposited on the wet surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated on Thursday. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes. In isolated cases the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released also by a single winter sport participant. In particular low altitudes: As the moisture increases more moist and wet snow slides are possible, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 20 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2400 m. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions there is still a very large amount of snow. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. The rain gave rise on Tuesday to thorough wetting of the snowpack below the tree line.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some regions up to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m. The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain sometimes large wind slabs will form. Below approximately 2300 m medium-sized to large wet loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2300 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind dry slab avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Especially in regions exposed to heavier precipitation and above approximately 2500 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is slightly greater.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of Tuesday can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2500 m.
The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
These avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.

In particular on very steep slopes and at intermediate and high altitudes medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. Dry avalanches can be released in near-surface layers.
In particular on very steep sunny slopes and at the base of rock walls small and medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Tuesday above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and snowfall above approximately 2300 m and the occasionally strong wind, a sometimes unfavourable avalanche situation developed on Tuesday.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack represent the main danger.

Isolated occasionally large moist avalanches have been released as a consequence of the rain.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular on very steep sunny slopes small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be an increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops. On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. Below approximately 1800 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall until Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate. Hardly any snow is lying at low and intermediate altitudes. The wind will be strong. New snow is lying mostly on a wet old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack will consolidate on Thursday. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be mild. Backcountry tours should be started and concluded very early.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Gliding avalanches can also occur, in particular on steep grassy slopes.
The wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering, especially adjacent to ridgelines. In all regions medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already be soft in the early morning. On sunny slopes the snowpack is wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mostly sunny. Over a wide area slight warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be partly cloudy.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Mostly small avalanches are possible in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already be soft in the early morning. On sunny slopes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mostly sunny. Over a wide area slight warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche conditions are generally favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops. Avalanches are small.

On steep grassy slopes small gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some snow will fall in some regions. As a consequence of falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate. Hardly any snow is lying at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of the new snow there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. Mostly avalanches are small.
Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.
On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 20 cm of snow will fall until Wednesday. Fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow will be deposited on the wet surface of an old snowpack. The wind will be moderate to strong. The fresh wind slabs are mostly only small.

As a consequence of falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate.

Below approximately 1800 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Rapid decrease in danger of dry avalanches. Gradual increase in danger of wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 2000 m: In gullies and bowls mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m snow will fall on Wednesday. The snowpack remains generally moist.
